of release scenarios

We performed an offsite consequence analysis (OCA) to estimate the potential for an accidental release to affect the public or the environment.  The OCA consists of evaluating worst-case release scenarios. We do not expect a worst-case release scenario to ever occur.  

The main objective of performing the OCA is to determine the distance at which an accidental release might affect the public (the endpoint distance).  The following could occur at the endpoint distance: Most people at the endpoint distance of a toxic substance release like TDI would be able to walk away from the exposure without any long-term health consequences, although some short-term consequences (e.g., strong eye or throat irritation) are likely.  Some people who are particularly susceptible to the released substance could be incapacitated.

	[Note: The following section entitled Worst-case release scenario is similar to those contained in EPA and industry guidance documents for risk management plans (RMPlans).  The EPA has decided not to include on the Internet the OCA data submitted in sections 2 Â¿ 5 of the RMPlan.  In January 1999, the EPA also revised its guidance on the scenario sections of the Executive Summary to delete an earlier instruction to identify the distance to the endpoints.  The current guidance remains to describe each of the plantÂ¿s scenarios but it has been revised for the plant to indicate whether the release has offsite impact.  The following scenario sections conform to this EPA guidance.]

Worst-case release scenario.  
Deleted per 4/19/2004 Rulemaking                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                                       

The general accidental release prevention program and specific prevention steps

The pl

BUSINESS CONFIDENTIAL

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

FLEXIBLE FOAM PRODUCTS, INC.
501 INDUSTRIAL BLVD.
TERRELL, TEXAS 75160

Flexible Foam, Inc. owns and operates a polyurethane foam manufacturing facility on 501 Industrial Boulevard.  Flexible Foam receives raw materials at its facility, mixes the materials to produce a polyurethane foam bun on a foam production line.  The foam is then cured and stored on site prior to shipping to customers.  Some limited fabrication takes place at the facility.  

One of the components used in the production of polyurethane foam is toluene diisocyanate (TDI).  This compound is subject to EPAÂ¿s Risk Management Rule.

Toluene diisocyanate is delivered to the 501 Industrial Boulevard facility in tank trucks.  The trucks are off-loaded to a storage tank located inside the building.  Because the storage of TDI takes place inside the building, the probability of release of toluene diisocyanate vapors into the atmosphere is reduced.  As a result, the impact of such a release on the surrounding community is minimized.  There are no inhabited receptors (buildings and people other than the Flexible facility) that would be impacted by the release of stored or unloaded toluene diisocyanate but undeveloped property beyond the property line to the East and South would be impacted by a worst-case scenario..  

Because there are public receptors (undeveloped) and there have been no significant incidents of release in the last five years, Flexible Foam, 501 Industrial Boulevard facility is classified as a Program 2 facility.


 WORST-CASE SCENARIO

DELETED in Accordance with 4/19/2004 Rulemaking

At the Flexible Products, Inc. (Flexible Foam) plant in Terrell, Texas, we handle toluene diisocyanate (TDI), which is considered hazardous and is regulated by the EPA.  The same properties that make TDI valuable for use at our facility also make it necessary to observe certain safety precautions in the handling of the substance.  TDI is considered a toxic substa

nce, and associated safety precautions have been implemented to (1) prevent unnecessary human exposure, (2) reduce the threat to the health of our employees at the Nu-Foam Chattanooga plant, and (3) reduce the threat to nearby members of our community.  It is our policy to adhere to all applicable federal and state rules and regulations.

We are committed to the safety of our employees and the public, and to the preservation of the environment, through the prevention of accidental releases of hazardous substances.  Successful implementation of our accidental release prevention program will help ensure that emergencies are unlikely and reduce the likelihood that emergency response procedures will be needed.  Nevertheless, an emergency such as a release of TDI is possible.  We have emergency response procedures to help ensure that accidents will be mitigated properly without undue risk to the public, environment, employees, contractors, or other personnel within the plant.

Description of the facility and the regulated substances handled

The primary purpose of this facility is to produce polyurethane foam, which is sold to other facilities and is used to produce furniture, bedding, carpet padding and a number of other products.  TDI is one of the reactants required to produce our polyurethane foam.  TDI is received by railcar and by tank truck, and is stored in two indoor storage tanks.  The maximum quantity of TDI stored in the process (i.e., in storage tanks and in up to two standby railcars) at our plant is about 200,000 lb.  The TDI is piped to a mix head where it is mixed with other reactants to produce a slab of polyurethane foam.  The foam products are shipped to customers by truck.

TDI is the only substance handled at our plant that is regulated by EPAÂ¿s risk management program (RMP) rule.  This substance is covered because the maximum quantity contained in our TDI process exceeds EPAÂ¿s threshold quantity of 10,000 lb for TDI.

Offsite consequence analysis

ant has implemented programs and procedures that comply with EPAÂ¿s Level 2 Accidental Release Prevention Program Rule.  Our facility qualifies for Level 1 coverage because (1) our worst-case release scenario for TDI cannot impact persons across the property boundary of the nearest public receptor, (2) TDI is exempt from OSHAÂ¿s process safety management standard, and (3) our polyurethane foam process has not been targeted by the EPA for Level 3 coverage.  
 
 The TDI process at our plant has hazards that must be managed to ensure continued safe operation.  The prevention program outlined above is applied to the TDI process.  Collectively, these prevention program activities help prevent potential accidental releases that could be caused by equipment failures, human errors, and management system failures.
 
 In addition to the accidental release prevention program, our plant has safety features on many units to help (1) quickly detect a release, (2) contain or control a release, and (3) reduce the consequences of or mitigate a release.  The following types of safety features are used in various units of the TDI process:
 
Â¿ Release Detection 
 
Â¿ Process alarms (e.g., high level alarms and flow cutoff relays on the TDI storage tanks)
Â¿ Continuous operator surveillance (e.g., during TDI tanker unloading and TDI supply to the foam process)
 
Â¿ Release Containment/Control
 
Â¿ Curbing or dikes to contain TDI liquid releases
Â¿ TDI storage tanks located inside an enclosed building
Â¿ Automated shutdown systems for critical process parameters (e.g., high pressure)
Â¿ Pressure relief devices on equipment to prevent rupture
Â¿ Valves to permit isolation of process equipment
Â¿ TDI railcar inner tank surrounded by an outer shell filled with insulation
Â¿ Vapor displaced from storage tanks during unloading is vented through a carbon filter
Â¿ Facility personnel in attendance whenever TDI is being transferred from a bulk deliver 
  vessel to storage tanks.
 
Â¿ Release Mi

tigation
Â¿ Fire suppression and extinguishing systems
Â¿ Trained emergency response personnel
Â¿ Personal protective equipment (e.g., protective clothing, self-contained breathing 
  apparatus)
 
 Five-year accident history
 
 We have had no releases of TDI in the last 5 years that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage off site.  We have had one small release of TDI inside the indoor contained tank room over the past 5 years.  That release was less than 100 lb of TDI and was quickly neutralized and remediated. The release was not large enough to result in injuries or significant damage and was exempt from reporting requirements due to the small quantity.
 
Emergency Action, Contingency and Severe Weather Plan
 
Our Emergency Action, Contingency and Severe Weather Plan is based on the requirements in OSHAÂ¿s emergency action plan regulation, and EPAÂ¿s contingency plan requirements.  Our program includes procedures for responding to a release of TDI.  HAZWOPER training for responding to and cleaning up small spills (up to ten gallons) will occur in 2006.  Larger spills or releases will require outside contractors for clean-up.  Our procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including proper first aid (in the MSDS which is Attachment 1) and medical treatment for exposures, evacuation plans and accounting for personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and post-incident cleanup and decontamination requirements.  Employees receive training in these procedures as necessary to perform their specific emergency response duties.  The emergency response program is updated when necessary, based on modifications made to plant processes or equipment/facilities, or if the plan fails in any way under emergency conditions.  Personnel affected by changes in the progra

m are informed and trained on those changes.
 
 The emergency response plan for the plant is coordinated with the LEPC.  This coordination includes providing them with a copy of the ERP and subsequent telephone call and invitation to tour the plant.  The plant has around-the-clock communications capability with the appropriate LEPC officials and emergency response organizations such as the fire department.  This provides a means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.  
 
 Planned changes to improve safety
 
Specific plans implemented are containment for entire railcar contents and automatic cutoff system connected to storage tank high-level alarms.  
 
 Past changes to improve safety

Â¿ Provided high-level alarm of the TDI and other feeds to prevent overfilling the TDI storage tanks.
 
Â¿ Revised operating procedures to resolve findings from the latest TDI process hazard review, conducted when the facility had filed for Program Level 2 (which was later found to be in error).

Â¿ Containment for entire single TDI railcar contents.
